unnormalised: ## My Loan Saga: From Hope to (Almost) Horror, and Back Again
normalised: ## My Loan Saga: From Hope to (Almost) Horror, and Back Again

unnormalised: My startup, "Chai & Code," was just an idea brewing in my head last year. But the dream of serving masala chai and coding tutorials from a cozy café in Bangalore needed capital. I needed a loan, a big one. After weeks of research, I settled on the "Startup Booster Loan" from a private bank, offering what seemed like a sweet deal: Rs. 50 lakhs at 9.5% interest. The EMIs were calculated, spreadsheets consulted, and hope blossomed.
normalised: My startup, "Chai and Code," was just an idea brewing in my head last year. But the dream of serving masala chai and coding tutorials from a cozy café in Bangalore needed capital. I needed a loan, a big one. After weeks of research, I settled on the "Startup Booster Loan" from a private bank, offering what seemed like a sweet deal: rupees fifty lakhs at nine point five percent interest. The E-M-Is were calculated, spreadsheets consulted, and hope blossomed.

unnormalised: The initial euphoria was intoxicating. I used the loan to secure a prime location near Koramangala, hired a fantastic chef named Fatima (whose samosas are legendary), and invested in top-notch equipment – a fancy coffee machine, high-powered laptops, and even a small stage for weekend open mic nights. My projected monthly revenue, according to my overly optimistic calculations, was ₹7.5 lakhs. We were set for success!

My projected monthly revenue, according to my overly optimistic calculations, was rupees seven point five lakhs. We were set for success!

unnormalised: Reality, as it often does, delivered a sharp jolt. The first few months were slow. Really slow. Foot traffic was lower than expected, the online marketing campaign wasn't yielding results, and Fatima’s legendary samosas, while delicious, weren't enough to cover the rent. I started dipping into my personal savings, a terrifying prospect. The EMI reminders from the bank loomed large. Repayment date was fast approaching and I didn't have enough to cover it.

I started dipping into my personal savings, a terrifying prospect. The E-M-I reminders from the bank loomed large. Repayment date was fast approaching and I didn't have enough to cover it.

unnormalised: Then came the first repayment date – 15/03/2024. Panic set in. I remember staring at the bank statement, the Rs. 62,500 EMI mocking me. I considered selling my car, a beloved Maruti Swift that had seen me through countless adventures. I even contemplated asking my parents for help, a move I desperately wanted to avoid.
normalised: Then came the first repayment date – fifteenth march two thousand and twenty four. Panic set in. I considered selling my car, a beloved Maruti Swift that had seen me through countless adventures. I even contemplated asking my parents for help, a move I desperately wanted to avoid.

unnormalised: I spent a sleepless night racking my brain, re-evaluating every decision. The next morning, fuelled by strong coffee and desperation, I implemented a complete overhaul. I partnered with a local tech college, offering discounts to students. I introduced a "Chai & Code" membership program with exclusive tutorials and events. And I even started offering "Coding with Chai" workshops for senior citizens.

unnormalised: Slowly, things started to turn around. The student discounts brought in a younger crowd. The membership program created a loyal customer base. And the senior citizen workshops, surprisingly, became a huge hit. Fatima even created a special "diabetic-friendly" samosa, which was a stroke of genius.

unnormalised: By June, the cafe started making a profit. Not a huge one, but enough to cover the EMIs and even put a little aside. The relief was immense. I remember making that first full repayment, feeling like I'd climbed Mount Everest. The stress lines on my face started to fade, and I could finally breathe again.

unnormalised: Now, two years down the line, "Chai & Code" is thriving. We've expanded our menu, hired more staff, and are even planning to open a second branch. I still get a shiver of anxiety when I think about those early days, the near-miss disaster. But it taught me invaluable lessons about resilience, adaptability, and the importance of a good samosa.

unnormalised: My loan saga wasn't just about money; it was about chasing a dream, facing challenges head-on, and learning to navigate the unpredictable currents of entrepreneurship. And it all started with a humble cup of chai and a whole lot of code. Looking at the balance left on my Rs 50 lakh loan, which now stands at Rs 12,34,567.89, I know I will get there.
